lines.text: Enter KING HENRY VI, QUEEN MARGARET, GLOUCESTER, CARDINAL, and SUFFOLK, with Falconers halloing

lines.speaker: queen margaret
lines.text: Believe me, lords, for flying at the brook, I saw not better sport these seven years' day: Yet, by your leave, the wind was very high; And, ten to one, old Joan had not gone out.

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: But what a point, my lord, your falcon made, And what a pitch she flew above the rest! To see how God in all his creatures works! Yea, man and birds are fain of climbing high.

lines.speaker: suffolk
lines.text: No marvel, an it like your majesty, My lord protector's hawks do tower so well; They know their master loves to be aloft, And bears his thoughts above his falcon's pitch.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: My lord, 'tis but a base ignoble mind That mounts no higher than a bird can soar.

lines.speaker: cardinal
lines.text: I thought as much; he would be above the clouds.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: Ay, my lord cardinal? how think you by that? Were it not good your grace could fly to heaven?

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: The treasury of everlasting joy.

lines.speaker: cardinal
lines.text: Thy heaven is on earth; thine eyes and thoughts Beat on a crown, the treasure of thy heart; Pernicious protector, dangerous peer, That smooth'st it so with king and commonweal!

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: What, cardinal, is your priesthood grown peremptory? Tantaene animis coelestibus irae? Churchmen so hot? good uncle, hide such malice; With such holiness can you do it?

lines.speaker: suffolk
lines.text: No malice, sir; no more than well becomes So good a quarrel and so bad a peer.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: As who, my lord?

lines.speaker: suffolk
lines.text: Why, as you, my lord, An't like your lordly lord-protectorship.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: Why, Suffolk, England knows thine insolence.

lines.speaker: queen margaret
lines.text: And thy ambition, Gloucester.

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: I prithee, peace, good queen, And whet not on these furious peers; For blessed are the peacemakers on earth.

lines.speaker: cardinal
lines.text: Let me be blessed for the peace I make, Against this proud protector, with my sword!

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: [Aside to CARDINAL]  Faith, holy uncle, would 'twere come to that!

lines.speaker: cardinal
lines.text: [Aside to GLOUCESTER]  Marry, when thou darest.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: [Aside to CARDINAL]  Make up no factious numbers for the matter; In thine own person answer thy abuse.

lines.speaker: cardinal
lines.text: [Aside to GLOUCESTER]  Ay, where thou darest not peep: an if thou darest, This evening, on the east side of the grove.

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: How now, my lords!

lines.speaker: cardinal
lines.text: Believe me, cousin Gloucester, Had not your man put up the fowl so suddenly, We had had more sport. Come with thy two-hand sword.
Aside to GLOUCESTER

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: True, uncle.

lines.speaker: cardinal
lines.text: [Aside to GLOUCESTER]  Are ye advised? the east side of the grove?

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: [Aside to CARDINAL]  Cardinal, I am with you.

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: Why, how now, uncle Gloucester!

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: Talking of hawking; nothing else, my lord. Now, by God's mother, priest, I'll shave your crown for this, Or all my fence shall fail.
Aside to CARDINAL

lines.speaker: cardinal
lines.text: [Aside to GLOUCESTER]  Medice, teipsum-- Protector, see to't well, protect yourself.

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: The winds grow high; so do your stomachs, lords. How irksome is this music to my heart! When such strings jar, what hope of harmony? I pray, my lords, let me compound this strife. Enter a Townsman of Saint Alban's, crying 'A miracle!'

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: What means this noise? Fellow, what miracle dost thou proclaim?

lines.speaker: townsman
lines.text: A miracle! a miracle!

lines.speaker: suffolk
lines.text: Come to the king and tell him what miracle.

lines.speaker: townsman
lines.text: Forsooth, a blind man at Saint Alban's shrine, Within this half-hour, hath received his sight; A man that ne'er saw in his life before.

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: Now, God be praised, that to believing souls Gives light in darkness, comfort in despair!
Enter the Mayor of Saint Alban's and his  brethren, bearing SIMPCOX, between two in a chair, SIMPCOX's Wife following

lines.speaker: cardinal
lines.text: Here comes the townsmen on procession, To present your highness with the man.

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: Great is his comfort in this earthly vale, Although by his sight his sin be multiplied.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: Stand by, my masters: bring him near the king; His highness' pleasure is to talk with him.

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: Good fellow, tell us here the circumstance, That we for thee may glorify the Lord. What, hast thou been long blind and now restored?

lines.speaker: simpcox
lines.text: Born blind, an't please your grace.

lines.speaker: wife
lines.text: Ay, indeed, was he.

lines.speaker: suffolk
lines.text: What woman is this?

lines.speaker: wife
lines.text: His wife, an't like your worship.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: Hadst thou been his mother, thou couldst have better told.

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: Where wert thou born?

lines.speaker: simpcox
lines.text: At Berwick in the north, an't like your grace.

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: Poor soul, God's goodness hath been great to thee: Let never day nor night unhallow'd pass, But still remember what the Lord hath done.

lines.speaker: queen margaret
lines.text: Tell me, good fellow, camest thou here by chance, Or of devotion, to this holy shrine?

lines.speaker: simpcox
lines.text: God knows, of pure devotion; being call'd A hundred times and oftener, in my sleep, By good Saint Alban; who said, 'Simpcox, come, Come, offer at my shrine, and I will help thee.'

lines.speaker: wife
lines.text: Most true, forsooth; and many time and oft Myself have heard a voice to call him so.

lines.speaker: cardinal
lines.text: What, art thou lame?

lines.speaker: simpcox
lines.text: Ay, God Almighty help me!

lines.speaker: suffolk
lines.text: How camest thou so?

lines.speaker: simpcox
lines.text: A fall off of a tree.

lines.speaker: wife
lines.text: A plum-tree, master.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: How long hast thou been blind?

lines.speaker: simpcox
lines.text: Born so, master.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: What, and wouldst climb a tree?

lines.speaker: simpcox
lines.text: But that in all my life, when I was a youth.

lines.speaker: wife
lines.text: Too true; and bought his climbing very dear.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: Mass, thou lovedst plums well, that wouldst venture so.

lines.speaker: simpcox
lines.text: Alas,  good master, my wife desired some damsons, And made me climb, with danger of my life.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: A subtle knave! but yet it shall not serve. Let me see thine eyes: wink now: now open them: In my opinion yet thou seest not well.

lines.speaker: simpcox
lines.text: Yes, master, clear as day, I thank God and Saint Alban.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: Say'st thou me so? What colour is this cloak of?

lines.speaker: simpcox
lines.text: Red, master; red as blood.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: Why, that's well said. What colour is my gown of?

lines.speaker: simpcox
lines.text: Black, forsooth: coal-black as jet.

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: Why, then, thou know'st what colour jet is of?

lines.speaker: suffolk
lines.text: And yet, I think, jet did he never see.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: But cloaks and gowns, before this day, a many.

lines.speaker: wife
lines.text: Never, before this day, in all his life.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: Tell me, sirrah, what's my name?

lines.speaker: simpcox
lines.text: Alas, master, I know not.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: What's his name?

lines.speaker: simpcox
lines.text: I know not.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: Nor his?

lines.speaker: simpcox
lines.text: No, indeed, master.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: What's thine own name?

lines.speaker: simpcox
lines.text: Saunder Simpcox, an if it please you, master.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: Then, Saunder, sit there, the lyingest knave in Christendom. If thou hadst been born blind, thou mightest as well have known all our names as thus to name the several colours we do wear. Sight may distinguish of colours, but suddenly to nominate them all, it is impossible. My lords, Saint Alban here hath done a miracle; and would ye not think his cunning to be great, that could restore this cripple to his legs again?

lines.speaker: simpcox
lines.text: O master, that you could!

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: My masters of Saint Alban's, have you not beadles in your town, and things called whips?

lines.speaker: mayor
lines.text: Yes, my lord, if it please your grace.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: Then send for one presently.

lines.speaker: mayor
lines.text: Sirrah, go fetch the beadle hither straight.
Exit an Attendant

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: Now fetch me a stool hither by and by. Now, sirrah, if you mean to save yourself from whipping, leap me over this stool and run away.

lines.speaker: simpcox
lines.text: Alas, master, I am not able to stand alone: You go about to torture me in vain.
Enter a Beadle with whips

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: Well, sir, we must have you find your legs. Sirrah beadle, whip him till he leap over that same stool.

lines.speaker: beadle
lines.text: I will, my lord. Come on, sirrah; off with your doublet quickly.

lines.speaker: simpcox
lines.text: Alas, master, what shall I do? I am not able to stand. After the Beadle hath hit him once, he leaps over the stool and runs away; and they follow and cry, 'A miracle!'

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: O God, seest Thou this, and bearest so long?

lines.speaker: queen margaret
lines.text: It made me laugh to see the villain run.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: Follow the knave; and take this drab away.

lines.speaker: wife
lines.text: Alas, sir, we did it for pure need.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: Let them be whipped through every market-town, till they come to Berwick, from whence they came. Exeunt Wife, Beadle, Mayor,  and c

lines.speaker: cardinal
lines.text: Duke Humphrey has done a miracle to-day.

lines.speaker: suffolk
lines.text: True; made the lame to leap and fly away.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: But you have done more miracles than I; You made in a day, my lord, whole towns to fly.
Enter BUCKINGHAM

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: What tidings with our cousin Buckingham?

lines.speaker: buckingham
lines.text: Such as my heart doth tremble to unfold. A sort of naughty persons, lewdly bent, Under the countenance and confederacy Of Lady Eleanor, the protector's wife, The ringleader and head of all this rout, Have practised dangerously against your state, Dealing with witches and with conjurers: Whom we have apprehended in the fact; Raising up wicked spirits from under ground, Demanding of King Henry's life and death, And other of your highness' privy-council; As more at large your grace shall understand.

lines.speaker: cardinal
lines.text: [Aside to GLOUCESTER]  And so, my lord protector, by this means Your lady is forthcoming yet at London. This news, I think, hath turn'd your weapon's edge; 'Tis like, my lord, you will not keep your hour.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: Ambitious churchman, leave to afflict my heart: Sorrow and grief have vanquish'd all my powers; And, vanquish'd as I am, I yield to thee, Or to the meanest groom.

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: O God, what mischiefs work the wicked ones, Heaping confusion on their own heads thereby!

lines.speaker: queen margaret
lines.text: Gloucester, see here the tainture of thy nest. And look thyself be faultless, thou wert best.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: Madam, for myself, to heaven I do appeal, How I have loved my king and commonweal: And, for my wife, I know not how it stands; Sorry I am to hear what I have heard: Noble she is, but if she have forgot Honour and virtue and conversed with such As, like to pitch, defile nobility, I banish her my bed and company And give her as a prey to law and shame, That hath dishonour'd Gloucester's honest name.

lines.speaker: king henry the sixth
lines.text: Well, for this night we will repose us here: To-morrow toward London back again, To look into this business thoroughly And call these foul offenders to their answers And poise the cause in justice' equal scales, Whose beam stands sure, whose rightful cause prevails.
Flourish. Exeunt
